text: Why do we love music?

Everybody has their own reasons.
But from an evolutionary perspective, our
love of music doesn’t make a lot of sense.
It didn’t contribute to our survival or help
our ancestors make babies.
It turns out that the key to your musical
feels might be chemistry.
[Reactions intro]
Music and Emotion A 2011 study from Valorie
Salimpoor and others looked at a group of people
who reliably got musical chills,
then asked them to make a playlist of
their favorite songs from any genre.

These people listened to the tracks while
scientists monitored their brain activity.

They found that music triggers the release
of a chemical called dopamine in a part of

the brain called the striatum. Evolutionarily,
this is a really old part of the brain associated
with responses to stuff that make you feel good.
This showed that listening to, say,

Daft Punk, affects the same areas of the
brain as chocolate, sex or cocaine.
This was the first study to reveal that an
abstract reward like listening to music could
release dopamine, as opposed to a
tangible reward like a delicious burrito.

It might also explain why people
LOVE paintings or other forms of art.
Chapter break: Tension and release
The study gives us a clue about why tension
and release is so important in music.

Let’s use what dance music fans
call "the drop" as an example.
It's that moment in every great show when
the audience is locked in with the performance.
Then all of a sudden, the beat “drops out”.
All that’s left is a quiet melody.
Then another element creeps in,
building dynamic tension.
Your pupils dilate.
Your heart rate goes up.
You're sweating.
Everybody in the audience is knows it's coming.
The DROP.
The beat returns, and the crowd explodes.
From The Isley Brothers' "Shout" to a huge EDM drop,
the tension and release in these songs make
for some amazing musical moments.
The study hints at why they feel so good.

We associate surges of dopamine with pleasure,
with the processing of actual rewards.
And the listeners had more dopamine release
in their brains during their favorite parts.
But surprisingly, there was also increased amounts
of dopamine in a slightly different part of
the brain BEFORE the listener got to
their favorite part of a song.
The authors called this the "anticipatory phase"
of listening, when our brains help us
predict the arrival of our favorite part.
Neuroscientists believe this region of the brain
is involved in creating learned responses to stimuli.
In this case, a change in a song's beat or melody
can be a cue that a reward is coming.
The same way Pavlov’s dogs started
drooling when they heard a buzzer,
a dancer’s brain starts releasing dopamine

during the breakdown of a song, knowing
that a musical rush is coming soon.

A great band or DJ can really get dopamine
levels rising in these moments.
The drop can be delayed or manipulated
to heighten the musical climax.
The great thing about this work is that it
extends to all genres. Music is subjective.

You can get your dopamine rush
from a house music buildup or
harmonic variations in classical music.
It may even explain why phish heads love a four
hour jam band set (even if we still don’t get it).
